title: Cat. 47 Tea Service, 1850
publication_title: American Silver in the Art Institute of Chicago
content:
<section class="osci-tk-epub-section tombstone" id="tombstone">Gorham & Thurber (American, 1850–1852)  
Providence, Rhode Island  
Silver; hot-water pot: 21.6 × 22.2 cm (8 1/2 × 8 3/4 in.); teapot: 22 × 23.9 × 14.6 cm (8 5/8 × 9 3/8 × 5 3/4 in.); covered milk pot: 21 × 15.9 × 12.1 cm (8 1/4 × 6 1/4 × 4 3/4 in.); covered cream pot: 17.2 × 14.9 × 11.4 cm (6 3/4 × 5 7/8 × 4 1/2 in.); covered sugar bowl: 18.4 × 16.2 × 16.2 cm (7 1/4 × 6 3/8 × 6 3/8 in.); waste bowl: 11.4 × 16.2 × 16.2 cm (4 1/2 × 6 3/8 × 6 3/8 in.)  
Hot-water pot: the Art Institute of Chicago, bequest of Mrs. Frederick H. Wickett, 1952.1107; remainder of service: Mary Swissler Oldberg Fund, 2015.606.1–5

</section><section class="osci-tk-epub-section curatorial_entry" id="curatorial_entry">Made during a particularly pivotal year of Gorham Manufacturing Company’s history, this tea service is a very early example of the Providence, Rhode Island, firm’s complexly formed and decorated hollowware. In 1848 founder Jabez Gorham left the business to his son John, who had joined the company in 1841 with ambitious plans for expansion and modernization. In 1850 the company changed its name to Gorham & Thurber to reflect the addition of John’s cousin, Gorham Thurber, which allowed John to focus on “the improvement of our machinery and tools, and especially [on] the introduction of Hollow Ware as Dinner & Tea Services, etc.” Gorham & Thurber chose to debut its new creations at the Rhode Island State Fair in 1850, where, the Providence Journal observed, “the tea and coffee sets are superbly elegant, perfect in design and execution and reflect the highest credit upon the manufacturers.” Recognizing the city’s first specimens of locally produced hollowware, the reporter noted that the “wealth of our city will see that it need not go abroad for the most luxurious ornaments for the table. Providence has long been distinguished by its manufacture of . . . silver ware; but hollow ware of silver has not, we believe, been before attempted here.”

Building upon its success, Gorham presented at the 1851 Rhode Island State Fair its most elaborate hollowware to date. The company’s Chinese tea service received first place in the department of “the graceful arts” and was given the fullest description in a Providence Journal article characterizing it as a “new and elegant model . . . fully chased, the body being surrounded by a succession of scenes peculiar to China, which are exquisitely rendered. The feet, spout, etc., are formed of the tea plant, bearing leaves, buds and blossoms . . . the effect of the whole is in the highest degree ornate and graceful (fig. 47.1).”

The service was designed by a New York silversmith who created the drawings and fashioned the wax models for applied elements for the firm’s craftsmen to execute in silver; according to John Gorham, the service took an unusually long time to complete. A drawing by Providence engravers Thompson & Crosby accompanied the newspaper article and was subsequently used by Gorham in an 1852 advertisement (see fig. 47.2) illustrating part of the service, which was praised in the press for its “extreme elegance of design and finished workmanship.”

The characterization of the 1851 Chinese service evokes the effect of the naturalistic branches bearing the flowers and foliage of the tea plant that wind around the Art Institute service’s cast crabstock handles and spouts, and malleably loop to form the feet of all the vessels. Provenance, along with the inscription on the kettle, dates the Art Institute’s set to the year before, 1850, when it was made for Emily Mandeville Almy (1827–1923), as indicated by the EMA and Almy engraved on either side of the vessels. She married Benjamin Rathbone Almy (1810–1861) on November 15, 1849, and the couple initially resided in Providence.

The elaborately wrought repoussé and chased scenes that cover the objects’ hand-raised, melon-shaped bodies tend to suggest their likely contents. The milk pot and the cream pot feature a cow, a barn, and a woman carrying a milk pail on her head; the teapot and the waste bowl are adorned with chinoiserie imagery of a hatted Asian figure carrying a parasol; a similar figure seated in a boat sailing in a pool, indicated by deftly formed hammer marks; and banks lushly populated with palms and exotic plants. The sugar bowl depicts a man tending a field of sugarcane. These vignettes are framed by the overhanging branches of tall trees, which also form the organic cartouches enclosing the engraved monogram and surname.

Known as Rococo Revival, the service’s style reflects America’s interest in the historicized aesthetics of eighteenth-century French Rococo, which melds asymmetrical and sinuous undulations of form with abundant floral flourishes, as well as Chinese-influenced scenes of Asian figures and architectural elements. This style was adopted by silver firms nationwide as early as the 1830s, becoming widespread from 1840 to 1860 in cities such as New York, Philadelphia, Boston, and especially Baltimore. In addition to French chinoiserie, imported Asian porcelain, lacquer, wallpaper, and silver provided inspiration for these profusely decorated wares. The height of Chinese export silver spanned the 1840s to the 1870s, with most known examples found in New England, a result of these states’ strong involvement with the China trade beginning in the late eighteenth century. Moving away from Western-influenced style that had been observed since the turn of the eighteenth century, Chinese export silver returned to the copiously ornamented examples made as early as the late seventeenth century with characteristic repoussé compositional scenes and finials, handles, spouts, and feet cast as branches, vines, and dragons. It is therefore not surprising to see American silver that combines chinoiserie elements with motifs that glorify the natural wonders of the United States and celebrate the young country.  
Elizabeth A. Williams
